item.title: Ticket #317 (Multiple copies of a plugin can be adding, leading to fatal errors) created
item.dc:creator: MC_incubus
item.description:
If you activate a plugin and doubleclick the "activate" link, it will activate two copies of the plugin, which leads to Fatal error: Cannot redeclare function_name()

plugins.php should make sure the plugin it is activating is not already activated!

item.title: Ticket #276 (trackback permalinks not generated) closed
item.dc:creator: ryan

item.title: Ticket #316 (Post with links to large file slows down) created
item.dc:creator: matt
item.description: When publishing a post with links to file like images or movies posting slows to a crawl. I assume this is because we're doing something wrong in the pingback code.

item.title: Ticket #315 (Adminitration Plugins panel throws lots of errors on ...) created
item.dc:creator: maijs
item.description:
when any of plugins was ever activated and then deactivated back, so that no active plugins remain, Administration Plugins panel throws lots of errors concerning arrays.

I assume it's because no checking is being made in scripts (./wp-settings.php, ./wp-admin/plugins.php) to check whether operations with arrays (in_array(), foreach(), $array[] =...) are really performed on arrays, and as when plugin is activated and then deactivated, 'active_plugins' option in db table becomes 'a:0:{}' which unserialized is not considered as array any more..

item.title: Ticket #312 (RSS feed is broken if using MarkDown and reference a URL with and ...) created
item.dc:creator: nozell
item.description:
If you are using MarkDown and reference a URL with a _ in it, the RSS2 feed (maybe the others too) will be invalid.

Example:

Here is a [sample](â€‹http://www.x.com/Some_Where/foo.html) of the problem.

The normal HTML does the right thing, but in the RSS feed the href looks like this:

<a href="â€‹http://www.x.com/Some_Where/foo.html">

Where it contains "Some ampersand pound 95 semicolon Where" instead of "Some underscore Where".

That URI is invalid.

I noticed this because a planetplanet aggregator died while processing my RSS2 feed.

Turning off MarkDown fixes the problem.

item.title: Ticket #311 (trackbacks get written to DB with empty values) updated
item.dc:creator: bronski
item.description: I missed a thing... check_comment is testing for $url, but the insert-statement is using $tb_url. Which obviously works well with comments?! The patch above is not linking the trackback for that reason.

item.title: Ticket #311 (trackbacks get written to DB with empty values) updated
item.dc:creator: bronski
item.description:
The two attached diffs make trackback work for me.

Comments and trackbacks seem to use a complete different set of variable names, comment uses author, email, url, and trackback comment_author, comment_author_email, comment_author_url etc.

item.title: Ticket #311 (trackbacks get written to DB with empty values) created
item.dc:creator: bronski
item.description:
trackbacks to posts never show up in the blog, but they are in the databse. Looking at wordpress_comments you can see all trackbacks have a post_ID of "0" and almost all other values are empty.

The reason for that is wp-trackback.php and wp-includes/functions-post.php make inconsistant use of variables. wp-trackback.php uses comment_post_id, wp-includes/functions-post.php uses both comment_post_id and comment_post_ID. The final insert into the database uses comment_post_ID, and so does wp-comments-post.php. That is why comments get written into database with the correct ID and trackbacks with an ID of "0".

While the variables comment_author, comment_author_email, comment_author_url, comment_content, comment_type still have the correct values in wp-trackback.php those values get lost in wp-includes/functions-post.php. this only happens for trackbacks and not for comments.

And btw.: wp-trackback.php uses commment_author (with 3 m) instead of comment_author.

item.title: Ticket #309 (die() ends wp-trackback.php before last action) created
item.dc:creator: bronski
item.description:
The last two lines of wp-trackback.php are:

trackback_response(0); do_action('trackback_post', $wpdb->insert_id);

function trackback_response always ends with "die()" so the last line never gets executed.

item.title: Ticket #308 (if .htaccess is not found, Permalinks panel in Administration throws ...) created
item.dc:creator: maijs
item.description:
I have a fresh checkout from CVS (2004-09-22) and therefore .htaccess is not created yet

When I go to Administration > Options > Permalinks, this panel throws a Warning:

Warning: file(C:\root\wordpress/.htaccess): failed to open stream: No such file or directory in C:\root\wordpress\wp-admin\admin-functions.php on line 429

Warning: implode(): Bad arguments. in C:\root\wordpress\wp-admin\admin-functions.php on line 429

After file is created, this message appears no more until .htaccess is removed again

item.title: Changeset [1703]: Some file editor improvements. New: Recently edited and editor sidebar.
item.dc:creator: saxmatt
item.description: Some file editor improvements. New: Recently edited and editor sidebar.

item.title: Ticket #300 (Blank settings when using ?showoptions=all get changed to "0") updated
item.dc:creator: MC_incubus
item.description: This appears to be due to a CVS database change that didn't make it into upgrade.php basically, everything got an option type of 1, so those with option type of 3 (for string) didn't get set to "" instead of "0" when submitted blank. The database is converted fine when upgrading from 1.2 Mingus, so there's not really a problem. Just, people who use an earlier CVS version should probably do a clean install when they upgrade to 1.3 final.
